title: 1 Samuel Chapter 12 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Samuel chapter 12 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 12 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Samuel Chapter 12.

questions.question: Who did Samuel say he had made king over Israel?
options: A king over you
A prophet over you
A judge over you
A priest over you
questions.correctAnswer: A king over you
questions.explanation: Samuel states he has made a king over Israel as per 1 Samuel 12:1.

questions.question: What did Samuel say about his own age?
options: I am young
I am old and grayheaded
I am middle-aged
I am strong and healthy
questions.correctAnswer: I am old and grayheaded
questions.explanation: Samuel describes himself as old and grayheaded in 1 Samuel 12:2.

questions.question: What did Samuel ask the people to witness against him?
options: Whose ox have I taken?
Whose land have I taken?
Whose house have I built?
Whose servant have I enslaved?
questions.correctAnswer: Whose ox have I taken?
questions.explanation: Samuel asks who he has wronged by taking an ox, an ass, or receiving bribes, as seen in 1 Samuel 12:3.

questions.question: Did the people accuse Samuel of defrauding or oppressing them?
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The people declared Samuel had not defrauded or oppressed them (1 Samuel 12:4).

questions.question: Who does Samuel say advanced Moses and Aaron?
options: The LORD
Pharaoh
The king of Moab
Samuel himself
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Samuel says the LORD advanced Moses and Aaron to lead Israel out of Egypt (1 Samuel 12:6).

questions.question: What did Samuel ask the people to do before the LORD to hear about His righteous acts?
options: Stand still
Sing a song
Offer sacrifices
Dance
questions.correctAnswer: Stand still
questions.explanation: Samuel tells the people to stand still so he can reason with them about the LORD's acts (1 Samuel 12:7).

questions.question: Who did the LORD send when Israel cried to Him after they forgot Him?
options: Jerubbaal, Bedan, Jephthah, and Samuel
Moses and Aaron
David and Solomon
Elijah and Elisha
questions.correctAnswer: Jerubbaal, Bedan, Jephthah, and Samuel
questions.explanation: The LORD sent these deliverers when Israel repented, as listed in 1 Samuel 12:11.

questions.question: What did the people say when Nahash king of the Ammonites came against them?
options: Nay; but a king shall reign over us
We will fight alone
We will pray to the LORD
We will surrender
questions.correctAnswer: Nay; but a king shall reign over us
questions.explanation: They requested a king to reign over them instead of relying solely on God as king (1 Samuel 12:12).

questions.question: What was Samuel's warning if the people did not obey the LORD's voice?
options: The hand of the LORD will be against you
You will be blessed
You will remain safe
You will prosper greatly
questions.correctAnswer: The hand of the LORD will be against you
questions.explanation: Samuel warned that disobedience would bring the LORD's hand against them, as in 1 Samuel 12:15.

questions.question: What natural event did Samuel call upon the LORD to send as a sign?
options: Thunder and rain
Fire from heaven
Earthquake
Windstorm
questions.correctAnswer: Thunder and rain
questions.explanation: Samuel prayed and the LORD sent thunder and rain to show the people's wickedness (1 Samuel 12:17-18).

questions.question: True or False: The people greatly feared the LORD and Samuel after the thunder and rain.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The people feared the LORD and Samuel after the sign as recorded in 1 Samuel 12:18.

questions.question: What did the people ask Samuel to do after seeing the sign of thunder and rain?
options: Pray for us
Judge us
Punish us
Ignore us
questions.correctAnswer: Pray for us
questions.explanation: They asked Samuel to pray so they would not die for their sin in asking for a king (1 Samuel 12:19).

questions.question: What did Samuel urge the people to do despite their wickedness?
options: Serve the LORD with all your heart
Abandon the LORD
Rebel against the LORD
Worship other gods
questions.correctAnswer: Serve the LORD with all your heart
questions.explanation: Samuel encouraged them to turn not aside, but to serve God wholeheartedly (1 Samuel 12:20).

questions.question: True or False: Samuel said the LORD will forsake his people because of their sins.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Samuel said the LORD will not forsake His people for His great name's sake (1 Samuel 12:22).

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'Only fear the LORD, and serve him in truth with all your ______:'
options: heart
mind
strength
soul
questions.correctAnswer: heart
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 12:24 instructs to serve the LORD with all your heart.

medium.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 12 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Samuel Chapter 12 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 12 teach us about integrity in leadership when Samuel asks the people if he has wronged anyone?
options: Samuel declares he has not defrauded or oppressed anyone
Samuel admits to taking bribes to blind his eyes
Samuel asks for forgiveness for his sins
Samuel refuses to answer their questions
questions.correctAnswer: Samuel declares he has not defrauded or oppressed anyone
questions.explanation: Samuel asserts his integrity by asking if he has taken anything or oppressed anyone, and the people confirm he has not (1 Samuel 12:3-5). This shows the importance of honesty and fairness in leadership.

questions.question: According to 1 Samuel 12, how should believers respond when they realize they have sinned and turned away from God?
options: Cry out to the LORD for deliverance and commit to serve Him
Ignore their sins and continue in their ways
Blame others for their troubles
Demand a king to rule over them
questions.correctAnswer: Cry out to the LORD for deliverance and commit to serve Him
questions.explanation: The people cried out to God, confessed their sin of forsaking Him, and promised to serve Him if He would deliver them (1 Samuel 12:10). This teaches repentance and renewed commitment to God.

questions.question: What does Samuel remind Israel about God's past faithfulness in 1 Samuel 12 that can encourage us in times of difficulty?
options: God delivered them from Egypt and their enemies through judges
God abandoned them when they sinned
God only helps kings, not common people
God requires payment for miracles
questions.correctAnswer: God delivered them from Egypt and their enemies through judges
questions.explanation: Samuel recounts how God raised up Moses, Aaron, and judges like Jerubbaal and Jephthah to deliver Israel, emphasizing God's faithfulness in past trials (1 Samuel 12:6-11). This encourages trust in God's provision.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with obeying God’s commands. Based on 1 Samuel 12, what warning would you share about disobedience?
options: Rebellion against God brings His hand of judgment
Disobedience has no consequences
God will always bless disobedience
Obedience is optional for leaders only
questions.correctAnswer: Rebellion against God brings His hand of judgment
questions.explanation: Samuel warns that if they do not obey the LORD, His hand will be against them as it was against their fathers (1 Samuel 12:15). This teaches the seriousness of obedience to God’s commands.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 12 illustrate the power of prayer in times of national crisis?
options: Samuel prayed and God sent thunder and rain to show His displeasure
Samuel ignored the people's sins and did nothing
Samuel advised them to fight their enemies by themselves
Samuel told them to stop praying
questions.correctAnswer: Samuel prayed and God sent thunder and rain to show His displeasure
questions.explanation: Samuel called on the LORD, and God sent thunder and rain during the wheat harvest to demonstrate the people's wickedness and remind them to fear God (1 Samuel 12:16-18). This shows prayer’s role in seeking God's intervention.

questions.question: What counsel does Samuel give to the people after God’s demonstration of thunder and rain in 1 Samuel 12?
options: Do not turn aside but serve the LORD with all your heart
Stop serving God and follow other gods
Ignore God’s warnings and continue sinning
Demand a new king immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Do not turn aside but serve the LORD with all your heart
questions.explanation: Samuel encourages the people to fear not, repent, and serve the LORD wholeheartedly, warning against turning after vain things (1 Samuel 12:20-21). This teaches wholehearted devotion to God.

questions.question: According to 1 Samuel 12, what reason does Samuel give for God not forsaking His people despite their sins?
options: Because of His great name's sake and His pleasure to make them His people
Because they are stronger than their enemies
Because Samuel is their king
Because they never sin
questions.correctAnswer: Because of His great name's sake and His pleasure to make them His people
questions.explanation: Samuel states that the LORD will not forsake His people for His great name’s sake and because it pleased Him to make them His people (1 Samuel 12:22). This highlights God’s mercy and commitment to His covenant.

questions.question: How does Samuel model intercessory prayer for others in 1 Samuel 12?
options: He commits to continue praying for the people despite their sins
He refuses to pray for sinners
He tells the people to pray for themselves only
He prays only for kings
questions.correctAnswer: He commits to continue praying for the people despite their sins
questions.explanation: Samuel says he would not cease to pray for the people and would teach them the right way, showing a heart of intercession (1 Samuel 12:23). This encourages believers to pray persistently for others.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Samuel 12, the people's desire for a king was an act of faith in God’s plan.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Samuel explains that asking for a king was an act of wickedness and rejection of the LORD as their king (1 Samuel 12:12,17). This shows that their demand was not faith but rebellion.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Samuel 12 teaches that obedience to God brings continued blessing to both the people and their king.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Samuel promises that if the people fear the LORD, serve Him, and obey His voice, both they and their king will continue following God and be blessed (1 Samuel 12:14). This highlights the blessing of obedience.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Samuel calls upon the people to fear the LORD and serve Him with _____ heart.
options: all your
half your
a grudging
no
questions.correctAnswer: all your
questions.explanation: Samuel urges the people to serve the LORD with all their heart, emphasizing sincere and complete devotion (1 Samuel 12:24). This teaches wholehearted service to God.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 12 encourage honesty and accountability within a community?
options: Samuel openly invites the people to witness if he wronged anyone and offers to restore it
Samuel refuses to answer any accusations
Samuel blames the people for his mistakes
Samuel hides his actions from the people
questions.correctAnswer: Samuel openly invites the people to witness if he wronged anyone and offers to restore it
questions.explanation: Samuel’s invitation to the people to testify against him if he took anything wrongly and his promise to restore it (1 Samuel 12:3) models transparency and responsibility in leadership.

questions.question: What does 1 Samuel 12 teach about the consequences of turning away from God and serving other gods?
options: God allowed oppressors to defeat them as discipline
God ignored their sins
They prospered without consequences
God gave them more kings
questions.correctAnswer: God allowed oppressors to defeat them as discipline
questions.explanation: The chapter records that when Israel forgot the LORD and served other gods, He sold them into the hands of enemies like Sisera and the Philistines (1 Samuel 12:9). This teaches that idolatry leads to judgment.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear after sinning. What encouragement from 1 Samuel 12 would you share?
options: Fear not; though wickedness was done, turn back and serve the LORD with all your heart
You are beyond hope and must despair
Stop praying and accept punishment silently
Only kings are forgiven
questions.correctAnswer: Fear not; though wickedness was done, turn back and serve the LORD with all your heart
questions.explanation: Samuel tells the people not to fear, but to repent and serve the LORD wholeheartedly despite their sins (1 Samuel 12:20). This offers hope and calls for sincere repentance.

questions.question: According to 1 Samuel 12, what is the result if the people continue to do wickedly after receiving God's instruction and warning?
options: Both the people and their king will be consumed
They will be rewarded with peace
They will receive a new king
They will prosper without consequences
questions.correctAnswer: Both the people and their king will be consumed
questions.explanation: Samuel warns that if they persist in wickedness, both they and their king will be destroyed (1 Samuel 12:25), teaching the seriousness of ongoing disobedience.

hard.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 12 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Samuel Chapter 12.

questions.question: In 1 Samuel 12, Samuel challenges the people to witness against him for any wrongdoing. What specific accusations does he deny?
options: Taking oxen or donkeys, defrauding, oppressing, or accepting bribes
Leading them into idolatry
Refusing to appoint a king
Failing to intercede for Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Taking oxen or donkeys, defrauding, oppressing, or accepting bribes
questions.explanation: Samuel explicitly denies taking oxen or donkeys, defrauding, oppressing, or accepting bribes as stated in 1 Samuel 12:3.

questions.question: What reason does Samuel give for Israel’s suffering under foreign oppressors before the establishment of the monarchy?
options: Because they forgot the LORD their God
Because they worshiped the LORD too zealously
Because they refused to obey Samuel
Because they had too many kings
questions.correctAnswer: Because they forgot the LORD their God
questions.explanation: Samuel explains in 1 Samuel 12:9 that Israel was sold into the hands of their enemies because they forgot the LORD their God.

questions.question: Which leaders does Samuel mention as being sent by the LORD to deliver Israel before his time?
options: Jerubbaal, Bedan, Jephthah, and Samuel
Moses, Aaron, Joshua, and Samuel
David, Solomon, Josiah, and Samuel
Elijah, Elisha, Samuel, and Nathan
questions.correctAnswer: Jerubbaal, Bedan, Jephthah, and Samuel
questions.explanation: Samuel lists Jerubbaal, Bedan, Jephthah, and himself as deliverers sent by the LORD in 1 Samuel 12:11, underscoring the pattern of God raising leaders in times of crisis.

questions.question: How does Samuel describe his own role and life in relation to the people of Israel?
options: He has walked before them from childhood until now
He has been a distant prophet
He was appointed only to appoint the king
He was a military leader for Israel
questions.correctAnswer: He has walked before them from childhood until now
questions.explanation: Samuel states in 1 Samuel 12:2 that he has walked before the people from childhood until the present, indicating a lifelong leadership and service.

questions.question: What is the significance of Samuel calling upon the LORD to send thunder and rain during wheat harvest?
options: It was a sign of God's displeasure and confirmation of their wickedness
It was a normal seasonal event
It symbolized God's blessing on the king
It was a way to celebrate the new king
questions.correctAnswer: It was a sign of God's displeasure and confirmation of their wickedness
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 12:17-18, the unusual thunder and rain during wheat harvest serve as a divine sign to make the people perceive the gravity of their sin in demanding a king.

questions.question: What covenantal warning does Samuel give regarding the relationship between obedience to the LORD and the continuation of the king's reign?
options: If you fear and obey the LORD, both you and the king will continue to follow Him
The king's reign is independent of the people's obedience
Obedience will bring immediate wealth to the king
The king will reign forever regardless of obedience
questions.correctAnswer: If you fear and obey the LORD, both you and the king will continue to follow Him
questions.explanation: Samuel teaches in 1 Samuel 12:14 that the continuation of both the people's well-being and the king's reign depends on fearing and obeying the LORD.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 12:22 reflect the theme of God's faithfulness despite Israel's failures?
options: The LORD will not forsake his people for his great name's sake
Israel will be abandoned if they sin
God punishes without mercy
The people must earn God's favor by works
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will not forsake his people for his great name's sake
questions.explanation: This verse emphasizes God's covenant faithfulness and His commitment to Israel because of His own glory, not just their merit.

questions.question: Which phrase best captures the literary device used in Samuel's speech when he asks the people to witness against him and then they respond 'He is witness'?
options: Chiasm
Metaphor
Hyperbole
Alliteration
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm
questions.explanation: The structure of Samuel's self-defense and the people's affirmation creates a chiastic pattern, emphasizing mutual accountability as seen in 1 Samuel 12:3-5.

questions.question: In the cultural context of ancient Israel, why was the people's request for a king considered a 'wickedness' according to Samuel?
options: Because it rejected the LORD as their true king
Because kings were forbidden by the Law of Moses
Because Samuel wanted to remain judge
Because kings demanded excessive taxes
questions.correctAnswer: Because it rejected the LORD as their true king
questions.explanation: Samuel explains in 1 Samuel 12:12 that asking for a human king was a rejection of God's kingship over Israel, which was seen as wickedness.

questions.question: What typological connection can be drawn between Moses and Samuel based on 1 Samuel 12?
options: Both served as mediators between God and Israel and led deliverance
Both were kings of Israel
Both were priests in the tabernacle
Both were prophets who never saw the Promised Land
questions.correctAnswer: Both served as mediators between God and Israel and led deliverance
questions.explanation: Samuel references Moses and Aaron in 1 Samuel 12:6-8, drawing a typological parallel as leaders who intercede for and deliver Israel.

questions.question: According to 1 Samuel 12, what is Samuel's personal commitment toward Israel despite their failures?
options: He will continue to pray for them and teach them the good and right way
He will abandon them to their fate
He will appoint a new king immediately
He will become their military leader
questions.correctAnswer: He will continue to pray for them and teach them the good and right way
questions.explanation: Samuel expresses in 1 Samuel 12:23 his commitment to praying for the people and instructing them in the right path despite their sins.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Only fear the LORD, and serve him in ______ with all your heart: for consider how great things he hath done for you.'
options: truth
fear
love
faith
questions.correctAnswer: truth
questions.explanation: Samuel commands the people in 1 Samuel 12:24 to serve the LORD in truth, emphasizing sincerity and wholehearted devotion.

questions.question: True or False: Samuel assures the people that if they continue to do wickedly, only the king will be consumed, not the people.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 12:25 warns that if the people do wickedly, both they and their king shall be consumed, indicating collective responsibility.

questions.question: What is the significance of Samuel addressing both the people and the king in his covenant stipulations?
options: It emphasizes that the king is subject to the same covenant with God as the people
It elevates the king above the people
It suggests the king acts independently of God
It shows Samuel’s preference for monarchy
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes that the king is subject to the same covenant with God as the people
questions.explanation: Samuel makes clear in 1 Samuel 12:14 and 12:25 that both king and people must obey God, reflecting covenantal equality under divine law.

questions.question: How does the chapter 12 foreshadow later biblical themes about kingship in Israel?
options: It foreshadows the tension between divine kingship and human monarchy
It praises all kings unconditionally
It denies the need for obedience to God under kings
It predicts the eternal reign of Saul
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the tension between divine kingship and human monarchy
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 12 highlights the tension that will persist throughout Israel’s history between the LORD as king and the human monarchs they desire.

theological.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 12 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Samuel Chapter 12 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What reason does Samuel give to the Israelites to testify against him if he has wronged them?
options: Whose ox or ass have I taken, or whom have I defrauded?
Why have I not chosen a king for you?
Who among you has rebelled against me?
Why have I forsaken the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Whose ox or ass have I taken, or whom have I defrauded?
questions.explanation: Samuel invites the people to witness against him if he has taken anything unjustly, demonstrating his integrity (1 Samuel 12:3). This reflects the biblical principle of leaders being accountable (Proverbs 29:14; Acts 20:28; 1 Peter 5:2-3).

questions.question: According to Samuel, who is witness against the Israelites for their request of a king?
options: The LORD and His anointed
Moses and Aaron
Samuel himself
The elders of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD and His anointed
questions.explanation: Samuel declares that the LORD and His anointed serve as witnesses to Israel’s actions, highlighting divine oversight over human governance (1 Samuel 12:5). This aligns with God's role as sovereign King (Psalm 47:7; Isaiah 43:10; Hebrews 1:8).

questions.question: Which leaders does Samuel mention as having delivered Israel in the past?
options: Jerubbaal, Bedan, Jephthah, and Samuel
David, Solomon, Elijah, and Elisha
Moses, Aaron, Joshua, and Caleb
Saul, Jonathan, Abner, and Joab
questions.correctAnswer: Jerubbaal, Bedan, Jephthah, and Samuel
questions.explanation: Samuel cites these judges as examples of God’s deliverance and leadership prior to the monarchy (1 Samuel 12:11). This underscores God’s covenant faithfulness through appointed leaders (Judges 6:12; Judges 11:29; Hebrews 11:32).

questions.question: What condition does Samuel give for the continued blessing of both the people and the king over them?
options: Fear the LORD, serve Him, obey His voice, and do not rebel
Offer sacrifices daily and observe all festivals
Build a temple for the LORD in Jerusalem
Conquer their enemies with military strength
questions.correctAnswer: Fear the LORD, serve Him, obey His voice, and do not rebel
questions.explanation: Samuel emphasizes obedience and reverence toward God as essential for covenantal blessing (1 Samuel 12:14). This echoes Deuteronomy 28:1-2 and New Testament teachings on obedience (John 14:15; Hebrews 12:28).

questions.question: What consequence does Samuel warn will come if the people rebel against the LORD's commandment?
options: The hand of the LORD will be against them as it was against their fathers
They will be exiled immediately
Their king will be taken captive
They will cease to exist as a nation
questions.correctAnswer: The hand of the LORD will be against them as it was against their fathers
questions.explanation: Samuel warns of divine judgment for rebellion, consistent with the covenantal principle of blessings for obedience and curses for disobedience (1 Samuel 12:15; Deuteronomy 28:15; Romans 1:18; Hebrews 10:30).

questions.question: What miraculous sign did Samuel call upon the LORD to perform to demonstrate Israel's wickedness in asking for a king?
options: Thunder and rain during wheat harvest
A sudden drought in the land
Earthquake shaking the assembly
Fire from heaven consuming the altar
questions.correctAnswer: Thunder and rain during wheat harvest
questions.explanation: Samuel called for thunder and rain at an unusual time, showing God’s power and Israel’s sinfulness (1 Samuel 12:17-18). This sign is reminiscent of God’s control over nature (Exodus 9:23-26; Psalm 29:3-9; Matthew 5:45).

questions.question: How did the people respond after the LORD sent thunder and rain as Samuel prayed?
options: They greatly feared the LORD and Samuel
They mocked the sign and asked for another
They asked Samuel to be their king instead
They immediately rebelled and complained
questions.correctAnswer: They greatly feared the LORD and Samuel
questions.explanation: The people’s fear demonstrated reverence for God and recognition of Samuel’s prophetic role (1 Samuel 12:18). This reflects biblical themes of fear of the LORD as the beginning of wisdom (Proverbs 1:7; Ecclesiastes 12:13).

questions.question: What did the people ask Samuel to do after seeing the sign of thunder and rain?
options: Pray for them so they would not die
Choose a king to lead them
Lead them into battle against their enemies
Offer a sacrifice to atone for their sins
questions.correctAnswer: Pray for them so they would not die
questions.explanation: Recognizing their sinfulness, the people appealed for intercession, reflecting the biblical role of the prophet as mediator (1 Samuel 12:19; Numbers 16:46-50; 1 Timothy 2:1-2).

questions.question: What does Samuel urge the people to do despite their wickedness in requesting a king?
options: Turn not aside from following the LORD and serve Him with all your heart
Reject the king and return to judges
Build a new altar to the LORD
Offer double sacrifices to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Turn not aside from following the LORD and serve Him with all your heart
questions.explanation: Samuel encourages repentance and wholehearted service, emphasizing God’s mercy and the possibility of restoration (1 Samuel 12:20; Joel 2:12-13; Luke 15:18-20).

questions.question: Samuel warns that following vain things will result in what outcome?
options: They cannot profit nor deliver
They will be blessed abundantly
They will find peace and rest
They will become kings themselves
questions.correctAnswer: They cannot profit nor deliver
questions.explanation: Following worthless things leads to emptiness and lack of salvation, contrasting with trust in God who delivers (1 Samuel 12:21; Psalm 146:3; Isaiah 45:22; John 14:6).

questions.question: Why does Samuel say that the LORD will not forsake His people?
options: Because it has pleased the LORD to make them His people
Because they have an army to defend themselves
Because they built a temple for Him
Because they obey all His laws perfectly
questions.correctAnswer: Because it has pleased the LORD to make them His people
questions.explanation: God’s covenant faithfulness and sovereign choice motivate His steadfast love (1 Samuel 12:22; Deuteronomy 7:6-8; Romans 11:28-29; 2 Timothy 2:13).

questions.question: What personal commitment does Samuel make regarding his relationship with the people?
options: He will continue to pray for them and teach them the good way
He will appoint new judges to rule over them
He will build a permanent temple for the LORD
He will lead them in battle against their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: He will continue to pray for them and teach them the good way
questions.explanation: Samuel expresses his pastoral role of intercession and instruction, modeling faithful leadership (1 Samuel 12:23; James 5:16; 1 Timothy 2:1; Ezekiel 34:11-16).

questions.question: What is the ultimate warning Samuel gives if the people continue to do wickedly?
options: They and their king shall be consumed
They will be exiled to a foreign land
They will lose the ark of the covenant
They will be abandoned by Samuel
questions.correctAnswer: They and their king shall be consumed
questions.explanation: Samuel warns of severe judgment for persistent sin, consistent with covenant curses (1 Samuel 12:25; Leviticus 26:14-39; Hebrews 10:26-31).

questions.question: How does Samuel describe his own age and status compared to the new king?
options: He is old and grayheaded, his sons are with them, and the king now walks before them
He is young and strong, and the king is inexperienced
He is a warrior, while the king is a priest
He is a foreigner, and the king is an Israelite
questions.correctAnswer: He is old and grayheaded, his sons are with them, and the king now walks before them
questions.explanation: Samuel contrasts his long service and aging with the newly established monarchy (1 Samuel 12:2). This highlights transition from prophetic to kingly leadership (Psalm 71:18; Isaiah 46:4).

questions.question: What does Samuel remind the people about their history when they cried unto the LORD in Egypt?
options: The LORD sent Moses and Aaron to deliver them
They built the tabernacle in the wilderness
They conquered the land of Canaan immediately
They received the law from Samuel
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD sent Moses and Aaron to deliver them
questions.explanation: Samuel recalls God’s past deliverance through Moses and Aaron, grounding his argument in the continuity of God’s saving acts (1 Samuel 12:6-8; Exodus 3:10; Deuteronomy 5:5; Hebrews 11:23-29).
